raw_text:
Johnson announces June retirement
 
 Former England captain Martin Johnson has announced he is to retire from rugby union at the end of the season.
 
 Johnson, who captained England to World Cup glory in 2003, will play his final match in June. Johnson won 84 England caps and quit Test rugby at the start of 2004, just two months after leading Sir Clive Woodward's team to victory in Sydney. The 34-year-old Leicester lock's final match will be his testimonial at Twickenham on 4 June. "I'm confident I have made the right decision to retire," said Johnson. "I'm sure there will be times next season when I'll wish I was out there playing for the Tigers, but you know when the time is right to go and I feel this is the right time. "I feel physically that I could play for another season, but playing week in and week out in the Premiership is a full-time occupation and I only want to be out there for the right reasons." Johnson will always be revered by England fans for captaining England to their dramatic World Cup win against Australia in Sydney, but his list of achievements does not stop at that.
 
 He is the only man to captain the Lions twice and he also led England to a Six Nations Grand Slam. Johnson also had huge success as captain of Leicester, guiding the Tigers to back to back Heineken Cup victories and several Premiership titles. Apart from his marvellous captaincy Johnson was also one of the finest second rows to ever play the game. Teak tough and physically intimidating, he ruled the rucks and mauls for the best part of a decade and was integral in England's rise to the top of the world game. His final appearance will be in his testimonial at Twickenham, where he will lead a team against a side captained by New Zealand winger Jonah Lomu. The All Black is aiming to return to action after a kidney transplant and Johnson expects it to be a memorable occasion. "This game against Jonah will be a great way to end the season and end my career," said Johnson. Lomu, rugby union's first global superstar after his exploits in the 1995 World Cup, said he was proud to be part of Johnson's farewell. "We hold him in such high esteem," said Lomu. "He is such a great leader and I am just honoured to be on the same pitch."

He will play his final match in June, with a testimonial against New Zealand's Jonah Lomu scheduled for 4 June.
Johnson has won 84 England caps and captained the team to World Cup glory in 2003.

smollm:1.7b: Johnson announces his retirement from rugby union at the end of the season.
Former England captain Martin Johnson has announced he is to retire from rugby union at the start of the season.
He won 84 England caps and quit Test rugby at the start of 2003, just two months after leading Sir Clive Woodward's team to victory in Sydney.
The 34-year-old Leicester lock's final match will be his testimonial at Twickenham on 4 June.
"I'm confident I have made the right decision to retire," said Johnson.
"I'm sure there will be times next season when I'll wish I was out there playing for the right reasons."
He is the only man to captain the Lions twice and he also led England to a Six Nations Grand Slam.
Johnson also had huge success as captain of Leicester, guiding the Tigers to back to back Heineken Cup victories and several Premiership titles.
Apart from his marvellous captaincy Johnson was also one of the finest second rows to ever play the game.
Teak tough and physically intimidating, he ruled the rucks and mauls for the best part of a decade and was integral in England's rise to the top of the world game.
His final appearance will be in his testimonial at Twickenham, where he will lead a team against a side captained by New Zealand winger Jonah Lomu.
The All Black is aiming to return to action after a kidney transplant and Johnson expects it to be a memorable occasion.
"This game against Jonah will be a great way to end the season and end my career," said Johnson.
Lomu, rugby union's first global superstar after his exploits in the 1995 World Cup, said he was proud to be part of Johnson's farewell.
"We hold him in such high esteem," said Lomu.
"He is such a great leader and I am just honoured to be on the same pitch."

He was England's captain in 2003 and has quit Test rugby early in 2004 after winning the 2004 Sydney Test.
He won 84 caps and will play his final match in June against Jonah Lomu at Twickenham.
Johnson is remembered for England, but he's also noted for his contributions as captain of Leicester, leading to back-to-back Heineken Cups and Premiership titles.
His quote reflects the balance between personal success and professional growth.
tinyllama:1.1b: Johnson announces June retirée, citing his desire to retire physically from playing for England but also guiding the Tigers during their back-to-back Grand Slam victories.
Johnson's final match will be in his testimonial at Twickenham, where he is expected to lead a team against a New Zealand side captained by Jonah Lo Mu.
The All Blacks legend anticipates it being an exciting occasion and hopes to return to action after undergoing kidney transplant surgery.

Lo Mu has described Johnson as a global superstar who holds him in high esteem, while former England captain Martin Johnson echoes these sentiments regarding his achievements and contribution to the sport.

His last testimonial match will be against a team captained by Jonah Lomu, who is recovering from a kidney transplant.
This will mark Johnson's final appearance in his career and the end of an era for English rugby.

He captained the British & Irish Lions twice and achieved a Six Nations Grand Slam.

Known for his physical prowess, Johnson will lead a team against Jonah Lomu in this farewell match.
Lomu, rugby union's first global superstar, expressed pride in being part of Johnson's retirement ceremony, highlighting the respect he holds for Johnson as a leader.
